column1: From among a cloud of proposals
column4: two great systems at length disentangled themselves. They were the English construction of built-up wrought iron coils
column5: and the Prussian construction of solid steel castings. Wrought-iron
column8: containing but a trace of carbon. Steel
column10: contains from 0.3 to 0.5 per cent of carbon; the larger the quantity of carbon
column11: the harder the steel. Since the early days of which I am now speaking
column12: great improvement has taken place in the qualities of both materials
column13: but more especially in that of steel. Still the same general characteristics were to be noted
column14: and it may be broadly stated
column15: that England chose confessedly the weaker material
column18: and safer to intrust with the lives of men; while Prussia selected the stronger but less manageable substance
column19: in the hope of improving its uniformity
column20: and rendering it thoroughly trustworthy. The difference in strength
column23: gun steel is about twice as strong as wrought iron.
